lines.text:
[to barman]
Whiskey... like you pour it for yourself.
Don't you know it's no fun to drink alone?
Not until after the first one.

[gesturing at the piano player]
Doesn't he ever stop playing?
Sam? It don't bother him, he's deaf.
You a stranger here?
[Haven turns to him, then turns back to the bar and downs his whiskey]

[to bartender]
What kind of whiskey was that?
On the bottle it says rye, but the way you take it I don't see what difference it makes.
I'll have another rye.
You didn't answer my question.
I'm a stranger everywhere.
You got a job?
Listen, soldier, I know that one too. 'Got a job, stranger? No? Why don't you join the army? Three meals a day, a place to sleep, nice warm uniform.'
It has a little more than that.
Yeah, it has one thing more. That I could never take. It's got second lieutenants.
You want to make this a personal matter? Alright.
I don't make it anything, soldier. You tried to sell me something, I didn't buy it. Why don't you beat it?
If I weren't in uniform I might teach you a few manners.
If you could teach me anything you wouldn't be in a uniform.
You couldn't be looking for trouble, could you?
I could, but I'm not.
Well that's fine. Because this is one of the best places west of the Atlantic Ocean to find it.
That was my first impression.
That lieutenant's a nice young boy.
I don't doubt it. But his mouth is too big... like your ears.
[Haven walks up to the table where Charlie and Prince are seated]

[to Prince, whom he previously encountered at the dice table]
You know, you look much better at this table.
And you must like to pick fights.
Only with second lieutenants.
We like second lieutenants here. You see, here everybody fights except the army.
I wouldn't know.
So, anyone who doesn't like the army...
I know what you mean. But I'm afraid I'll have to come back. You see, I like the way you sing.
[Haven goes back to the saloon. Charlie is singing, but stops when she sees him enter, and sits down at a nearby table. Haven approaches the table]
Every time I come in here you stop singing. Why is that?
You don't have to come in.
Look, I didn't come back to start a fight or break the bank.
Why did you come back?

[sitting down]
If you'll invite me to sit down, I might find out.
It might be better if you found another table... and another girl.
Oh no it wouldn't. I looked.
[They both look over to Mick and Prince, who are standing a few paces away nervously exchanging glances]

[not yet aware that the woman he's talking to is Charlie]
Would that be Charlie?
No.
His eyes follow you around like a couple of flies.
They follow me around to see that strangers don't annoy me.
Only strangers?
No-one else would be so foolish.

[to waiter]
Waiter, bring me a bottle of wine, will you?
[to Charlie]
First you're beautiful, then I like the way you sing, and now you're a woman of mystery. I don't want to be a stranger, so I'll have to be foolish.
You like to take chances, don't you?
If I feel lucky.
I advise you to try the dice table.
I'd rather get lucky here.

[shrugs]
Every man has the right to his own funeral.
[Charlie gets Prince's attention. He approaches the table]

[noting Prince's approach]
I could be your cousin from Waxahachie. I could be cousin John, a missionary on his way to China.
[Prince joins Haven and Charlie at the table]
So Charlie probably runs the town, huh?
Why do you care?
I've gotta spend some time here, I'd just like to know who winds the clock.
[Haven throws his chips onto the table in front of Prince. Mick notices this, and walks over]

[sarcastically]
It's been a nice conversation. I'd hate to have it end.
Who's this?
Mick, this is cousin John.
From Waxahachie.
Cousin John's a missionary on his way to China.
What's keeping him?
Think he's wondering if he couldn't do more good here.
[Mick tries to remove the bottle of win, but Haven stops him]
You ain't too friendly, are ya?
I like to pick my friends.
You oughtta learn not to pick 'em so easy, like you do your cousins.

[gesturing at Charlie]
Ask her.
I never saw him before in my life.

[Haven and Mick are still wrestling over the bottle. Haven suddenly throws a glass of wine in Mick's face, and punches him. Haven is then held by various bystanders. Mick wipes his face and squares up to Haven]
You're too little to make that big a mistake.
You gonna correct me, or just bleed at the mouth?

[to the men holding Haven]
Bring him outside.
[Mick and Haven are going outside to fight]
What happened?
He wanted to be my cousin.
And she hasn't any aunts or uncles.
